docs.lead_paragraph: Many scholars say mandatory sentencing policies lock up nonviolent, low-level offenders for too long and are no longer a cost-effective way to reduce crime in the United States.

headline.main: For Lesser Crimes, Rethinking Life Behind Bars
headline.print_headline: For Lesser Crimes, Rethinking Life Behind Bars

docs.abstract: Many scholars say mandatory sentencing policies lock up nonviolent, low-level offenders for too long, are no longer a cost-effective way to reduce crime in the United States and may even be promoting it; criticism is resonating with some state and federal officials, who have started taking steps to stop the growth of America's prison population, which is currently at 2.3 million, the highest reported incarceration rate of any country (Series: Time and Punishment).
docs.snippet: Many scholars say mandatory sentencing policies lock up nonviolent, low-level offenders for too long and are no longer a cost-effective way to reduce crime in the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: European officials have warned Mexican and Canadian slaughterhouses that the meat of American racehorses may be too toxic to eat safely because of repeated drug injections.

headline.seo: Doping at U.S. Tracks Affects Europe’s Taste for Horse Meat
headline.main: Racetrack Drugs Put Europe Off U.S. Horse Meat
headline.print_headline: Drugs Injected at the Racetrack Put Europe Off U.S. Horse Meat

docs.abstract: European food safety officials warn Mexican and Canadian slaughterhouses that meat of American racehorses may be too toxic to eat because of repeated drug injections; officials indicate that they may require lifetime medication records for slaughter-bound horses from Canada and Mexico; action is latest sign of troubled state of American racing and its problems with doping horses.
docs.snippet: European officials have warned Mexican and Canadian slaughterhouses that the meat of American racehorses may be too toxic to eat safely because of repeated drug injections.
